oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Effects of the Environment on Neonatal Dairy Calf Health
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hancock, Dale
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: environmental factors
dairy calf mortality
dairy calf morbidity.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The data seem to support a conclusion that infection with a variety of diarrheal and respiratory agents is an inevitable part of being a calf and that infection need not be totally prevented in order to minimize disease losses. It appears, from a functional standpoint, that in the triad of disease causality (agent, host, environment) host and environmental factors predominate. This article will examine the effects of several environmental factors on dairy calf mortality and morbidity. Diagnosis of excess dairy calf morbidity /mortality requiresa detailed analysis of management practices including those related to the environment. Simply looking for infectious agents will accomplish little since the same agents can be found on low as well as high morbidity /mortality rate farms.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: American Association of Bovine Practitioners Conference Proceedings; 1983; 85-87
